page.title: List of fictional characters within The Simpsons

rev.comment: rm fair use overuse of character images. See [[Wikipedia:NFC#Non-free_image_use_in_list_articles]]
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
{{NFimageoveruse|Date=April 2008}}
 
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}}
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}}
Although ''[[The Simpsons]]'' is itself a show populated by [[fictional character]]s (see [[List of characters from The Simpsons|List of characters from ''The Simpsons'']]), save celebrities who make [[Cameo appearance|cameos]] as themselves, there are a number of characters within the show's universe who are [[Fictional fictional character|fictional to the ''Simpsons'' characters]] themselves.
Although ''[[The Simpsons]]'' is itself a show populated by [[fictional character]]s (see [[List of characters from The Simpsons|List of characters from ''The Simpsons'']]), save celebrities who make [[Cameo appearance|cameos]] as themselves, there are a number of characters within the show's universe who are [[Fictional fictional character|fictional to the ''Simpsons'' characters]] themselves.
Line 11: Line 10:
===Fallout Boy===
===Fallout Boy===
â
[[Image:fallout-boy.png|left|200px|thumb|Fallout Boy]]
 
In the series, Fallout Boy first appeared in a [[1950s]] ''[[Radioactive Man (The Simpsons character)|Radioactive Man]]'' film [[Serial (film)|serial]] shown at a comic book convention in the episode "[[Three Men and a Comic Book]]", and it was implied that the actor who played Fallout Boy might have been gay. However, unlike many ''Simpsons'' characters, he has only made a handful of appearances since. While Radioactive Man is a broad parody of many superheroes, most obviously containing elements of [[Batman]] and [[Superman]] (and the comic incorporates an origin story similar to [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]]'s [[The Hulk]]), among others, Fallout Boy is mainly a parody of Robin (with his costume, references as being the 'young ward' of Radioactive Man, and his younger age and sidekick status) with elements of Spider-Man (his fictional comic book origin, for example). His catchphrase: "Jiminy jillickers!"
In the series, Fallout Boy first appeared in a [[1950s]] ''[[Radioactive Man (The Simpsons character)|Radioactive Man]]'' film [[Serial (film)|serial]] shown at a comic book convention in the episode "[[Three Men and a Comic Book]]", and it was implied that the actor who played Fallout Boy might have been gay. However, unlike many ''Simpsons'' characters, he has only made a handful of appearances since. While Radioactive Man is a broad parody of many superheroes, most obviously containing elements of [[Batman]] and [[Superman]] (and the comic incorporates an origin story similar to [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]]'s [[The Hulk]]), among others, Fallout Boy is mainly a parody of Robin (with his costume, references as being the 'young ward' of Radioactive Man, and his younger age and sidekick status) with elements of Spider-Man (his fictional comic book origin, for example). His catchphrase: "Jiminy jillickers!"
Line 37: Line 35:
===McBain===<!-- This section is linked from [[Ross Perot]] -->
===McBain===<!-- This section is linked from [[Ross Perot]] -->
â
[[Image:McBainSimpsons.png|200px|right|thumb|Wolfcastle as McBain]]
 
McBain is a movie [[action hero]] played by fictional actor [[Rainier Wolfcastle]], a parody of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and [[Bruce Willis]] (his name is a play on the character of [[John McClane]] from the ''[[Die Hard]]'' movies) for their film personae, and also Clint Eastwood in the ''Dirty Harry'' movies. McBain movies feature many action movie [[clichÃ©]]s, such as a policeman being gunned down just before retirement, and [[one-liner joke|one-liners]] before dispatching enemies. The villain for at least one of his movies (if not the whole series) appears to be "Senator Mendoza." The films also parody ''[[The Terminator]]'' in many respects. Some of his movies include, ''McBain: You Have the Right to Remain Dead'', ''McBain: Let's Get Silly'' (''"The entire movie is me standing against a brick wall for an hour and a half. It cost 80 million dollars."''), and the ''McBain'' films up to ''McBain 5: The Final Chapter''. Rainier Wolfcastle, McBain and clips of his movies also appear in the cartoon [[The Critic]].
McBain is a movie [[action hero]] played by fictional actor [[Rainier Wolfcastle]], a parody of [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and [[Bruce Willis]] (his name is a play on the character of [[John McClane]] from the ''[[Die Hard]]'' movies) for their film personae, and also Clint Eastwood in the ''Dirty Harry'' movies. McBain movies feature many action movie [[clichÃ©]]s, such as a policeman being gunned down just before retirement, and [[one-liner joke|one-liners]] before dispatching enemies. The villain for at least one of his movies (if not the whole series) appears to be "Senator Mendoza." The films also parody ''[[The Terminator]]'' in many respects. Some of his movies include, ''McBain: You Have the Right to Remain Dead'', ''McBain: Let's Get Silly'' (''"The entire movie is me standing against a brick wall for an hour and a half. It cost 80 million dollars."''), and the ''McBain'' films up to ''McBain 5: The Final Chapter''. Rainier Wolfcastle, McBain and clips of his movies also appear in the cartoon [[The Critic]].
Line 48: Line 45:
===Ozmodiar===
===Ozmodiar===
â
[[Image:Ozmodiar.png|left|thumb|200px|Ozmodiar the Great]]
 
Ozmodiar is a parody of [[the Great Gazoo]] from ''[[The Flintstones]]'' and is said to only be seen by [[Homer Simpson]]. However, he has been seen speaking briefly to Bart and Lisa in "[[HOMR]]". Also, he has spoken to [[Troy McClure]] in the "[[The Simpsons Spin-Off Showcase]]" episode where Ozmodiar was introduced.
Ozmodiar is a parody of [[the Great Gazoo]] from ''[[The Flintstones]]'' and is said to only be seen by [[Homer Simpson]]. However, he has been seen speaking briefly to Bart and Lisa in "[[HOMR]]". Also, he has spoken to [[Troy McClure]] in the "[[The Simpsons Spin-Off Showcase]]" episode where Ozmodiar was introduced.
Line 66: Line 62:
==One-time fictional characters==
==One-time fictional characters==
===Amendment To Be===
===Amendment To Be===
â
[[Image:Amendment to be.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Amendment to be]]
 
Sings a right-wing parody of the 70s [[Schoolhouse Rock]] educational song "[[I'm Just A Bill]]" in "[[The Day the Violence Died]]". He is voiced by [[Jack Sheldon]], the original voice of the [[Schoolhouse Rock]] shorts.
Sings a right-wing parody of the 70s [[Schoolhouse Rock]] educational song "[[I'm Just A Bill]]" in "[[The Day the Violence Died]]". He is voiced by [[Jack Sheldon]], the original voice of the [[Schoolhouse Rock]] shorts.
Line 73: Line 68:
===Death===
===Death===
â
[[Image:Death Simpsons.png|right|200px|thumb|Death at the door]]
 
In the 'Reaper Madness' segment of "[[Treehouse of Horror XIV]]", [[Death (personification)|Death]] comes for Bart. After a comical around-the-house chase ([[Yakety Sax]] is played as background music), Homer kills Death (in revenge for "[[Snowball I]] and [[John F. Kennedy|JFK]]") with a bowling ball. After dumping the bones in the trash, Homer tries on Death's robe. The flesh of his arm quickly rots away as he realises that he has become the new Grim Reaper. Homer soon becomes used to being Death and having a skeletal appendage that, when touching people, kills them. He is sent to claim the life of Jasper, one of the residents at the [[Springfield Retirement Castle]]. When he sees that Homer has filled the position, the old man inquires, "Where's the regular guy? Where's Doug?" Homer informs Jasper that he has taken over for him, to which Jasper wistfully replies "Aw, I liked Doug." Homer then kills him.
In the 'Reaper Madness' segment of "[[Treehouse of Horror XIV]]", [[Death (personification)|Death]] comes for Bart. After a comical around-the-house chase ([[Yakety Sax]] is played as background music), Homer kills Death (in revenge for "[[Snowball I]] and [[John F. Kennedy|JFK]]") with a bowling ball. After dumping the bones in the trash, Homer tries on Death's robe. The flesh of his arm quickly rots away as he realises that he has become the new Grim Reaper. Homer soon becomes used to being Death and having a skeletal appendage that, when touching people, kills them. He is sent to claim the life of Jasper, one of the residents at the [[Springfield Retirement Castle]]. When he sees that Homer has filled the position, the old man inquires, "Where's the regular guy? Where's Doug?" Homer informs Jasper that he has taken over for him, to which Jasper wistfully replies "Aw, I liked Doug." Homer then kills him.
Line 80: Line 74:
===Lisa Lionheart===
===Lisa Lionheart===
â
<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Lisa_Lionheart.jpg|thumb|Lisa Lionheart dolls]] -->
 
Lisa Lionheart is a [[doll]] created by [[Lisa Simpson]] and Stacy Lovell. It was designed as competition for the Malibu Stacy line of dolls. When it was first released, all the young girls, as well as [[Waylon Smithers]], were after it, but were literally intercepted in the store before they could reach the display of dolls by a cart of Talking Malibu Stacy dolls with new hats, leading to the complete failure of Lisa Lionheart.
Lisa Lionheart is a [[doll]] created by [[Lisa Simpson]] and Stacy Lovell. It was designed as competition for the Malibu Stacy line of dolls. When it was first released, all the young girls, as well as [[Waylon Smithers]], were after it, but were literally intercepted in the store before they could reach the display of dolls by a cart of Talking Malibu Stacy dolls with new hats, leading to the complete failure of Lisa Lionheart.
Line 86: Line 79:
===Mr. Sparkle===
===Mr. Sparkle===
â
[[Image:Mr sparkle.png|thumb|right|200px|Mr. Sparkle's TV ad]]
 
{{nihongo|Mr. Sparkle|ãã¹ã¿ã¼ã¹ãã¼ã³ã«|MisutÄ SupÄkoru}} is a Japanese dishwashing [[detergent]] mascot who bears a strong resemblance to [[Homer Simpson|Homer Simpson]] that "banished dirt to the land of wind and ghosts." Voiced by [[Sab Shimono]] in "[[In Marge We Trust]]". Homer spends the majority of the episode thinking his likeness was being used without his permission until a video from Mr. Sparkle's parent company explains it came from combining a cartoon fish and a light bulb that were the logos of two Japanese companies that sponsor Mr. Sparkle, Matsumoto Fishworks and Tamarabuchi Heavy Manufacturing Concern. To sum up the explanation provided by the video, Bart says to Homer, "There's your answer, fishbulb." Mr. Sparkle appears in ''[[The Simpsons Game]]'' speaking English as part of an 'upcoming' Simpsons game, 'The Super Happy Fun-Fun Game' and is voiced by [[Hank Azaria]]. His advertisement also reappears in [[Funeral for a Fiend]].
{{nihongo|Mr. Sparkle|ãã¹ã¿ã¼ã¹ãã¼ã³ã«|MisutÄ SupÄkoru}} is a Japanese dishwashing [[detergent]] mascot who bears a strong resemblance to [[Homer Simpson|Homer Simpson]] that "banished dirt to the land of wind and ghosts." Voiced by [[Sab Shimono]] in "[[In Marge We Trust]]". Homer spends the majority of the episode thinking his likeness was being used without his permission until a video from Mr. Sparkle's parent company explains it came from combining a cartoon fish and a light bulb that were the logos of two Japanese companies that sponsor Mr. Sparkle, Matsumoto Fishworks and Tamarabuchi Heavy Manufacturing Concern. To sum up the explanation provided by the video, Bart says to Homer, "There's your answer, fishbulb." Mr. Sparkle appears in ''[[The Simpsons Game]]'' speaking English as part of an 'upcoming' Simpsons game, 'The Super Happy Fun-Fun Game' and is voiced by [[Hank Azaria]]. His advertisement also reappears in [[Funeral for a Fiend]].
===Worker and Parasite===
===Worker and Parasite===
â
<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Workerandparasite.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Worker and Parasite]] -->
 
Worker and Parasite are a cartoon cat and mouse, vaguely similar to Itchy and Scratchy, who appear during the episode "[[Krusty Gets Kancelled]]". When Itchy and Scratchy move to the [[Gabbo]] show, which competes briefly with the [[Krusty the Clown]] show, Krusty is forced to air a popular Russian cartoon called ''Worker and Parasite'' as a replacement. He introduces them as "Eastern Europe's favorite cat and mouse team". The cartoon begins with an introduction in foreign words. The cartoon then rolls and they hop around insanely and speak an unintelligible language. They eventually jump into a furnace and are heard muttering what sounds like "so much fire!" The end credits simply read "Endut Hoch Hech!" When it finishes, a completely dumbfounded Krusty exclaims, "What the hell was that?"
Worker and Parasite are a cartoon cat and mouse, vaguely similar to Itchy and Scratchy, who appear during the episode "[[Krusty Gets Kancelled]]". When Itchy and Scratchy move to the [[Gabbo]] show, which competes briefly with the [[Krusty the Clown]] show, Krusty is forced to air a popular Russian cartoon called ''Worker and Parasite'' as a replacement. He introduces them as "Eastern Europe's favorite cat and mouse team". The cartoon begins with an introduction in foreign words. The cartoon then rolls and they hop around insanely and speak an unintelligible language. They eventually jump into a furnace and are heard muttering what sounds like "so much fire!" The end credits simply read "Endut Hoch Hech!" When it finishes, a completely dumbfounded Krusty exclaims, "What the hell was that?"
Line 97: Line 88:
The '''Angelica Button''' series parodies the [[Harry Potter]]. The books were written by T.R. Francis. It has been mentioned in two episodes.
The '''Angelica Button''' series parodies the [[Harry Potter]]. The books were written by T.R. Francis. It has been mentioned in two episodes.
